children.value: This lecture introduces some elementary mathematics and trigonometry.

Useful and interesting in its own right, these concepts reap substantial rewards when studying dynamics generated
by linear difference equations or linear differential equations.

For example, these tools are keys to understanding outcomes attained by Paul
Samuelson (1939)

in his classic paper on interactions
between the investment accelerator and the Keynesian consumption function, our
topic in the lecture

In addition to providing foundations for Samuelson’s work and extensions of
it, this lecture can be read as a stand-alone quick reminder of key results
from elementary high school trigonometry.

children.value:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.rcParams["figure.figsize"] = (11, 5)  #set default figure size
import numpy as np
from sympy import (Symbol, symbols, Eq, nsolve, sqrt, cos, sin, simplify,
                  init_printing, integrate)

children.html: z=1+3iz = 1 + \sqrt{3} iz=1+3​i
z=1+3iz = 1 + \sqrt{3} iz=1+3​i
x=1x = 1x=1
y=3y = \sqrt{3}y=3​
r=2r = 2r=2
θ=tan⁡−1(3)=π3=60o\theta = \tan^{-1}(\sqrt{3}) = \frac{\pi}{3} = 60^oθ=tan−1(3​)=3π​=60o

children.value: Let’s use Python to plot the trigonometric form of the complex number

children.html: z=1+3iz = 1 + \sqrt{3} iz=1+3​i

children.value:
# Abbreviate useful values and functions
π = np.pi


# Set parameters
r = 2
θ = π/3
x = r * np.cos(θ)
x_range = np.linspace(0, x, 1000)
θ_range = np.linspace(0, θ, 1000)

# Plot
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(8, 8))
ax = plt.subplot(111, projection='polar')

ax.plot((0, θ), (0, r), marker='o', color='b')          # Plot r
ax.plot(np.zeros(x_range.shape), x_range, color='b')       # Plot x
ax.plot(θ_range, x / np.cos(θ_range), color='b')        # Plot y
ax.plot(θ_range, np.full(θ_range.shape, 0.1), color='r')  # Plot θ

ax.margins(0) # Let the plot starts at origin

ax.set_title("Trigonometry of complex numbers", va='bottom',
    fontsize='x-large')

ax.set_rmax(2)
ax.set_rticks((0.5, 1, 1.5, 2))  # Less radial ticks
ax.set_rlabel_position(-88.5)    # Get radial labels away from plotted line

ax.text(θ, r+0.01 , r'$z = x + iy = 1 + \sqrt{3}\, i$')   # Label z
ax.text(θ+0.2, 1 , '$r = 2$')                             # Label r
ax.text(0-0.2, 0.5, '$x = 1$')                            # Label x
ax.text(0.5, 1.2, r'$y = \sqrt{3}$')                      # Label y
ax.text(0.25, 0.15, r'$\theta = 60^o$')                   # Label θ

ax.grid(True)
plt.show()

children.html: (r(cos⁡θ+isin⁡θ))n=rneinθ=rn(cos⁡nθ+isin⁡nθ)(r(\cos{\theta} + i \sin{\theta}))^n = r^n e^{in\theta} = r^n(\cos{n\theta} + i \sin{n\theta})(r(cosθ+isinθ))n=rneinθ=rn(cosnθ+isinnθ)

children.value: To prove de Moivre’s theorem, note that

children.html: (r(cos⁡θ+isin⁡θ))n=(reiθ)n(r(\cos{\theta} + i \sin{\theta}))^n = \big( re^{i\theta} \big)^n(r(cosθ+isinθ))n=(reiθ)n

children.value: We can use de Moivre’s theorem to show that

children.html: r=x2+y2r = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}r=x2+y2​

1=eiθe−iθ=(cos⁡θ+isin⁡θ)(cos⁡(-θ)+isin⁡(-θ))=(cos⁡θ+isin⁡θ)(cos⁡θ−isin⁡θ)=cos⁡2θ+sin⁡2θ=x2r2+y2r2\begin{aligned} 1 &= e^{i\theta} e^{-i\theta} \\ &= (\cos{\theta} + i \sin{\theta})(\cos{(\text{-}\theta)} + i \sin{(\text{-}\theta)}) \\ &= (\cos{\theta} + i \sin{\theta})(\cos{\theta} - i \sin{\theta}) \\ &= \cos^2{\theta} + \sin^2{\theta} \\ &= \frac{x^2}{r^2} + \frac{y^2}{r^2} \end{aligned}1​=eiθe−iθ=(cosθ+isinθ)(cos(-θ)+isin(-θ))=(cosθ+isinθ)(cosθ−isinθ)=cos2θ+sin2θ=r2x2​+r2y2​​
x2+y2=r2x^2 + y^2 = r^2x2+y2=r2

children.value: For each element of a sequence of integers

children.html: n=0,1,2,…,n = 0, 1, 2, \ldots, n=0,1,2,…,

children.value: To do so, we can apply de Moivre’s formula.

children.html: xn=azn+aˉzˉn=peiω(reiθ)n+pe−iω(re−iθ)n=prnei(ω+nθ)+prne−i(ω+nθ)=prn[cos⁡(ω+nθ)+isin⁡(ω+nθ)+cos⁡(ω+nθ)−isin⁡(ω+nθ)]=2prncos⁡(ω+nθ)\begin{aligned} x_n &= az^n + \bar{a}\bar{z}^n \\ &= p e^{i\omega} (re^{i\theta})^n + p e^{-i\omega} (re^{-i\theta})^n \\ &= pr^n e^{i (\omega + n\theta)} + pr^n e^{-i (\omega + n\theta)} \\ &= pr^n [\cos{(\omega + n\theta)} + i \sin{(\omega + n\theta)} + \cos{(\omega + n\theta)} - i \sin{(\omega + n\theta)}] \\ &= 2 pr^n \cos{(\omega + n\theta)} \end{aligned}xn​​=azn+aˉzˉn=peiω(reiθ)n+pe−iω(re−iθ)n=prnei(ω+nθ)+prne−i(ω+nθ)=prn[cos(ω+nθ)+isin(ω+nθ)+cos(ω+nθ)−isin(ω+nθ)]=2prncos(ω+nθ)​

children.value: This example provides  machinery that is at the heard of Samuelson’s analysis of his multiplier-accelerator model

(z2−c1z−c2)=(z−z1)(z−z2)=0(z^2 - c_1 z - c_2 ) = (z - z_1)(z- z_2) = 0(z2−c1​z−c2​)=(z−z1​)(z−z2​)=0

children.value: In this example, we set the initial values: -

children.html: r=0.9r = 0.9r=0.9
θ=14π\theta = \frac{1}{4}\piθ=41​π
x0=4x_0 = 4x0​=4

children.value:
package based on the above initial
condition:

# Set parameters
r = 0.9
θ = π/4
x0 = 4
x1 = 2 * r * sqrt(2)

# Define symbols to be calculated
ω, p = symbols('ω p', real=True)

# Solve for ω
## Note: we choose the solution near 0
eq1 = Eq(x1/x0 - r * cos(ω+θ) / cos(ω), 0)
ω = nsolve(eq1, ω, 0)
ω = float(ω)
print(f'ω = {ω:1.3f}')

# Solve for p
eq2 = Eq(x0 - 2 * p * cos(ω), 0)
p = nsolve(eq2, p, 0)
p = float(p)
print(f'p = {p:1.3f}')
Using the code above, we compute that

children.html: ω=0\omega = 0ω=0
p=2p = 2p=2

children.value: Then we plug in the values we solve for

children.html: ω\omegaω
ppp

children.value:
# Define range of n
max_n = 30
n = np.arange(0, max_n+1, 0.01)

# Define x_n
x = lambda n: 2 * p * r**n * np.cos(ω + n * θ)

# Plot
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 8))

ax.plot(n, x(n))
ax.set(xlim=(0, max_n), ylim=(-5, 5), xlabel='$n$', ylabel='$x_n$')

# Set x-axis in the middle of the plot
ax.spines['bottom'].set_position('center')
ax.spines['right'].set_color('none')
ax.spines['top'].set_color('none')
ax.xaxis.set_ticks_position('bottom')
ax.yaxis.set_ticks_position('left')

ticklab = ax.xaxis.get_ticklabels()[0] # Set x-label position
trans = ticklab.get_transform()
ax.xaxis.set_label_coords(31, 0, transform=trans)

ticklab = ax.yaxis.get_ticklabels()[0] # Set y-label position
trans = ticklab.get_transform()
ax.yaxis.set_label_coords(0, 5, transform=trans)

ax.grid()
plt.show()

We can obtain a complete suite of trigonometric identities by
appropriately manipulating polar forms of complex numbers.
We’ll get many of them by deducing implications of the equality

children.html: ei(ω+θ)=eiωeiθe^{i(\omega + \theta)} = e^{i\omega} e^{i\theta}ei(ω+θ)=eiωeiθ

children.value: For example, we’ll calculate identities for

children.html: cos⁡(ω+θ)\cos{(\omega + \theta)}cos(ω+θ)
sin⁡(ω+θ)\sin{(\omega + \theta)}sin(ω+θ)

children.value:
Using the sine and cosine formulas presented at the beginning of this
lecture, we have:

children.html: cos⁡(ω+θ)=ei(ω+θ)+e−i(ω+θ)2sin⁡(ω+θ)=ei(ω+θ)−e−i(ω+θ)2i\begin{aligned} \cos{(\omega + \theta)} = \frac{e^{i(\omega + \theta)} + e^{-i(\omega + \theta)}}{2} \\ \sin{(\omega + \theta)} = \frac{e^{i(\omega + \theta)} - e^{-i(\omega + \theta)}}{2i} \end{aligned}cos(ω+θ)=2ei(ω+θ)+e−i(ω+θ)​sin(ω+θ)=2iei(ω+θ)−e−i(ω+θ)​​

children.value: We can also obtain the trigonometric identities as follows:

children.html: cos⁡(ω+θ)+isin⁡(ω+θ)=ei(ω+θ)=eiωeiθ=(cos⁡ω+isin⁡ω)(cos⁡θ+isin⁡θ)=(cos⁡ωcos⁡θ−sin⁡ωsin⁡θ)+i(cos⁡ωsin⁡θ+sin⁡ωcos⁡θ)\begin{aligned} \cos{(\omega + \theta)} + i \sin{(\omega + \theta)} &= e^{i(\omega + \theta)} \\ &= e^{i\omega} e^{i\theta} \\ &= (\cos{\omega} + i \sin{\omega})(\cos{\theta} + i \sin{\theta}) \\ &= (\cos{\omega}\cos{\theta} - \sin{\omega}\sin{\theta}) + i (\cos{\omega}\sin{\theta} + \sin{\omega}\cos{\theta}) \end{aligned}cos(ω+θ)+isin(ω+θ)​=ei(ω+θ)=eiωeiθ=(cosω+isinω)(cosθ+isinθ)=(cosωcosθ−sinωsinθ)+i(cosωsinθ+sinωcosθ)​

children.value:
Since both real and imaginary parts of the above formula should be
equal, we get:

children.html: cos⁡(ω+θ)=cos⁡ωcos⁡θ−sin⁡ωsin⁡θsin⁡(ω+θ)=cos⁡ωsin⁡θ+sin⁡ωcos⁡θ\begin{aligned} \cos{(\omega + \theta)} = \cos{\omega}\cos{\theta} - \sin{\omega}\sin{\theta} \\ \sin{(\omega + \theta)} = \cos{\omega}\sin{\theta} + \sin{\omega}\cos{\theta} \end{aligned}cos(ω+θ)=cosωcosθ−sinωsinθsin(ω+θ)=cosωsinθ+sinωcosθ​

children.value: The equations above are also known as the

. We
can verify the equations using the

# Define symbols
ω, θ = symbols('ω θ', real=True)

# Verify
print("cos(ω)cos(θ) - sin(ω)sin(θ) =",
    simplify(cos(ω)*cos(θ) - sin(ω) * sin(θ)))
print("cos(ω)sin(θ) + sin(ω)cos(θ) =",
    simplify(cos(ω)*sin(θ) + sin(ω) * cos(θ)))

We can also compute the trigonometric integrals using polar forms of
complex numbers.
For example, we want to solve the following integral:

children.html: ∫−ππcos⁡(ω)sin⁡(ω) dω\int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \cos(\omega) \sin(\omega) \, d\omega∫−ππ​cos(ω)sin(ω)dω

∫cos⁡(ω)sin⁡(ω) dω=∫(eiω+e−iω)2(eiω−e−iω)2i dω=14i∫e2iω−e−2iω dω=14i(−i2e2iω−i2e−2iω+C1)=−18[(eiω)2+(e−iω)2−2]+C2=−18(eiω−e−iω)2+C2=12(eiω−e−iω2i)2+C2=12sin⁡2(ω)+C2\begin{aligned} \int \cos(\omega) \sin(\omega) \, d\omega &= \int \frac{(e^{i\omega} + e^{-i\omega})}{2} \frac{(e^{i\omega} - e^{-i\omega})}{2i} \, d\omega \\ &= \frac{1}{4i} \int e^{2i\omega} - e^{-2i\omega} \, d\omega \\ &= \frac{1}{4i} \bigg( \frac{-i}{2} e^{2i\omega} - \frac{i}{2} e^{-2i\omega} + C_1 \bigg) \\ &= -\frac{1}{8} \bigg[ \bigg(e^{i\omega}\bigg)^2 + \bigg(e^{-i\omega}\bigg)^2 - 2 \bigg] + C_2 \\ &= -\frac{1}{8} (e^{i\omega} - e^{-i\omega})^2 + C_2 \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \bigg( \frac{e^{i\omega} - e^{-i\omega}}{2i} \bigg)^2 + C_2 \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \sin^2(\omega) + C_2 \end{aligned}∫cos(ω)sin(ω)dω​=∫2(eiω+e−iω)​2i(eiω−e−iω)​dω=4i1​∫e2iω−e−2iωdω=4i1​(2−i​e2iω−2i​e−2iω+C1​)=−81​[(eiω)2+(e−iω)2−2]+C2​=−81​(eiω−e−iω)2+C2​=21​(2ieiω−e−iω​)2+C2​=21​sin2(ω)+C2​​
∫−ππcos⁡(ω)sin⁡(ω) dω=12sin⁡2(π)−12sin⁡2(−π)=0\int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \cos(\omega) \sin(\omega) \, d\omega = \frac{1}{2}\sin^2(\pi) - \frac{1}{2}\sin^2(-\pi) = 0∫−ππ​cos(ω)sin(ω)dω=21​sin2(π)−21​sin2(−π)=0

children.value: We can verify the analytical as well as numerical results using

# Set initial printing
init_printing(use_latex="mathjax")

ω = Symbol('ω')
print('The analytical solution for integral of cos(ω)sin(ω) is:')
integrate(cos(ω) * sin(ω), ω)
We invite the reader to verify analytically and with the

children.html: ∫−ππcos⁡(ω)2 dω=π\int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \cos (\omega)^2 \, d\omega = \pi∫−ππ​cos(ω)2dω=π
∫−ππsin⁡(ω)2 dω=π\int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \sin (\omega)^2 \, d\omega = \pi∫−ππ​sin(ω)2dω=π
π\piπ
